metadata.title: MCV4U – 2.2 Power Rule
metadata.creator: Thiago
metadata.abstract: This document is for testing purposes only. The material that is presented here should be treated as an example only.

section.p: In this module we will cover the Power rule for derivatives. The Power rule in calculus is a fairly simple rule that helps you find the derivative of a variable raised to a power, such as: $f(x) = x^{n} $, where $n\neq0 $. The Power rule simplifies our life because we won't have to take these sometimes complicated limits to find the Slope of a Tangent line at any given point.
You are probably already familiar with the definition of a derivative limit: $ \lim_{ \triangle x \rightarrow 0}=\frac{f(x + \triangle x)-f(x)}{\triangle x} $
